column2: Proximate cause was human error and violation of procedures. The unsafe reactor design caused instability at low power due to a positive Void coefficient and steam formation. When an improper test was conducted at 1:00 am at low power, the reactor became Void coefficient. This was followed by a Void coefficient that exposed the fuel, a raging fire, and a Void coefficient. The fire lasted for days to weeks, and there is controversy over whether it was the fuel burning, nuclear decay heating or whether the Void coefficient moderator that made up most of the core was involved. See Void coefficient, Note 1, for more discussion.
column3: The plants were not designed with consideration of such a large Tsunami. Subsequent review did not lead to mitigation. A major Tsunami caused the destruction of power lines and backup generators. Once the plants were without external power and the generators were flooded, a catastrophic Tsunami casualty ensued, leading to major reactor plant damage including Tsunami and explosive loss of Tsunami.[ Tsunami ]
